channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Blast at Political Rally in Pakistan Kills at Least 43 and Wounds 200
item.description: An explosion at a political rally on Sunday in northwest Pakistan killed dozens of people and injured 200 more, officials said, the latest sign of the deteriorating security situation in Pakistan, where some militant groups have become more active over the past two years.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Outside a hospital on Sunday after an explosion in Bajaur, a district in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province near Pakistan’s border with Afghanistan.

item.title: Niger Coup: West African Leaders Impose Sanctions and Threaten Military Action
item.description: A demand for a restoration of democracy echoed calls by the United States and France, major security allies of Niger.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Protesting the French military’s presence outside the French Embassy in Niamey, Nigeria, on Sunday.

item.title: A Climate Warning from the Cradle of Civilization
item.description: How extreme temperatures and dwindling water are pushing the Fertile Crescent toward the brink.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Bryan Denton
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times

item.title: Nero’s Theater Believed to Be Found in Rome
item.description: A dig at a palace set to become a hotel has unearthed traces of a theater that archaeologists hypothesize was built by Nero, the emperor with a disputed reputation for tyranny and debauchery.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: An archaeological dig at a Renaissance palazzo in Rome brought to light traces of the first-century theater that Emperor Nero built to indulge his inner artist.

item.title: Ukraine Recaptures Staromaiorske, a Glimmer of Success for Counteroffensive
item.description: Recapturing the village of Staromaiorske was such welcome news for the country that President Volodymyr Zelensky announced it himself. But formidable Russian defenses have stymied progress elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall

item.title: Israeli Court Ruling May Determine Democracy’s Fate
item.description: From Hungary to India to Brazil, how judges responded to attacks on their independence helped decide whether would-be autocrats prevailed in constraining the courts.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon
item.media:description: Demonstrators blocking traffic Monday on a highway in Tel Aviv during a protest against plans by Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to overhaul the country’s judicial system.

item.title: Could the Conflict in Manipur Become an Issue Modi Cannot Ignore?
item.description: India’s opposition is trying to force the prime minister to address the violence in Manipur, which has killed more than 150 people and displaced 60,000 others.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed house in the Churachandpur district of Manipur State, where widespread clashes began in early May.

item.title: Russia Says Ukrainian Drones Hit Moscow Buildings in Latest Attacks
item.description: The strike was the third in the past week in Moscow, a sign of how no city in Russia or Ukraine appears to be safe from the war. Russia blamed Ukraine, which has yet to comment.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: An office building in Moscow after a drone attack on Sunday.

item.title: In Odesa, Attacks Stoke Hatred of Russia
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia views Odesa as a culturally important part of his nation. But many in the Ukrainian city reject the connection and view the country that has been attacking it with loathing.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Colombian President’s Son Is Arrested in Money Laundering Inquiry
item.description: The arrest of Nicolás Petro poses another test for President Gustavo Petro, who has struggled to push many of his reforms through a divided Congress.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Nicolás Petro, right, and his father, Gustavo Petro, the Colombian president, in Bogotá, Colombia, in 2022. The younger Mr. Petro was arrested on money laundering charges on Saturday.

item.title: Coups in Africa Run Coast to Coast After Niger Turmoil
item.description: This past week’s military takeover in Niger completed a domino chain of countries ruled by leaders who seized power by force, fueling instability and presenting a conundrum for the United States.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Supporters of the military coup celebrating in Niamey, Niger, on Thursday.

item.title: Wildfires and Heat Transform Italy and Greece Into Tourism Nightmares
item.description: Record heat and wildfires have turned summer holidays into nightmares and called into question the future of cherished tourist destinations.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alberto Lo Bianco/LaPresse, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Residents watched a fire sweep across a hillside near Palermo in Sicily on Wednesday.

item.title: A Sense of Mission at Risk as Israeli Reservists Resign to Protest New Law
item.description: Military reservists are key to Israel’s defense capacity and a shared sense of national mission. But scores of reservists have resigned over a new law curbing judicial power, reflecting a widening rift in Israeli society.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Israeli military reservists protested near the Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv last week against plans to overhaul the judicial system.

item.title: Wildfires Are Displacing Canada’s Indigenous Communities
item.description: The country’s record-breaking fire season has led tens of thousands of Indigenous people to flee their homes and ravaged forests they rely on for sustenance.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Matt Joycey and Ben Laffin
item.media:credit: Matt Joycey for The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Dozens Dead in Pakistan
item.description: Also, Narendra Modi’s silence on Manipur and Iraq’s climate destruction.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: People carried coffins to collect bodies of victims outside a hospital following a blast in Bajaur, Pakistan, on Sunday.

item.title: Russian Propaganda on Ukraine Appears in Minecraft and Other Video Games
item.description: Propaganda is appearing in Minecraft and other popular games and discussion groups as the Kremlin tries to win over new audiences.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Kellen Browning
item.media:description: In the World of Tanks video game, a recreation of the Soviet Union’s parade of tanks in Moscow in 1945.

item.title: ‘We Are a Romantic Country’: On the Set of a Steamy Hit in Italy
item.description: Italy falls for “Mare Fuori,” a television melodrama about the inmates of a juvenile detention center who pass the time making out — when not scowling at or occasionally stabbing one another.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fans of the “Mare Fuori” television series cheering as Massimiliano Caiazzo, one of the show’s stars, left the set this month in Naples, Italy.

item.title: Ancient Worms Revived From Permafrost After 46,000 Years
item.description: Scientists want to understand how the worms survived in extreme conditions for extraordinarily long periods of time.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquin
item.media:credit: Alexei V. Tchesunov and Anastasia Shatilovich/Institute of Physicochemical and Biological Problems in Soil Science RAS, via Reuters
item.media:description: A scanning electron picture of a female Panagrolaimus kolymaensis nematode roundworm.

item.title: Biden Presses Ahead With Effort to Broker Israeli-Saudi Deal
item.description: The president sent Jake Sullivan, his national security adviser, on the latest diplomatic mission seeking to forge ties between Saudi Arabia and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Ronen Bergman
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, returned to Saudi Arabia on a diplomatic mission, his second such trip in recent months.

item.title: U.S. Hunts Chinese Malware That Could Disrupt American Military Operations
item.description: American intelligence officials believe the malware could give China the power to disrupt or slow American deployments or resupply operations, including during a Chinese move against Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A fighter jet taking off from Anderson Air Force Base in Guam earlier this year. The Chinese code, the officials say, appears directed at ordinary utilities that often serve both civilian populations and nearby military bases.

item.title: Russia Strikes Ukrainian Grain Terminal, Kyiv Says
item.description: In St. Petersburg, President Vladimir V. Putin rejected calls for reviving a Black Sea grain deal or for ending fighting.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian port of Odesa, which has been regularly targeted since Russia pulled out of a deal to allow grain exports from Ukraine through the Black Sea.

item.title: Trudeau Reshuffles His Cabinet
item.description: Canada’s prime minister revamped his cabinet, demoting some ministers and reassigning key portfolios to get in fighting form for an election.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during a news conference on Wednesday with cabinet ministers behind him at Rideau Hall in Ottawa.

item.title: ‘Evacuated for the Fifth Time’: Worst Wildfires in Canadian History Persist
item.description: Wildfires in Canada have forced the displacement of thousands of residents. In Northern Quebec, evacuees from the Cree Nation recently returned home after the smoke cleared, only to evacuate yet again after the fires reignited days later.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Matt Joycey and Ben Laffin
item.media:credit: Matt Joycey for The New York Times

item.title: Australia to Fast-Track Missile Production for U.S. Exports
item.description: The announcement of this plan, along with steps to expand joint military exercises, was shadowed by the news of a helicopter crash during one such exercise.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Australian Defense Minister Richard Marles and Foreign Minister Penny Wong taking part in a news conference on Saturday in Brisbane, Australia, along with their U.S. counterparts: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III.

item.title: Ukraine Launches Missile Strikes in Russia, Moscow Says
item.description: Kyiv did not take responsibility for the attacks, which could be a bid to broaden a war that has mostly rained ruin and death on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A photograph circulated on the Telegram channel of Vasily Golubev, governor of the Rostov region, showed the site of the blast in Taganrog, Russia, on Friday.

item.title: AIDS Relief Program Under Threat as G.O.P. Insists on Abortion Restriction
item.description: A decades-old program created by President George W. Bush to combat AIDS around the world is at risk of being sucked into a partisan dispute over abortion, with some Republicans threatening to block its renewal.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
item.media:credit: Lori Waselchuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse counsels a patient applying to join a free H.I.V. treatment program funded by PEPFAR in Lusaka, Zambia, in 2004.

item.title: Brazil Declines to Extradite Accused Russian Spy to U.S.
item.description: Analysts had seen the Russian as a potential candidate in a prisoner swap with Russia, which holds two Americans on spying charges, Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Paulo Motoryn
item.media:credit: From left: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters, Sofia Sandurskaya/Moscow News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, from left, a Wall Street Journal reporter who was arrested in Russia in March, and Paul Whelan, a former U.S. Marine who was arrested on espionage charges.

item.title: An ‘Oppenheimer’ Reading List
item.description: Seeing the new Christopher Nolan film about the physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, and the project to build the first atomic bomb? Our columnist has some recommendations for reading.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Scientists and workers at the Trinity Test Site near Alamogordo, N.M.

item.title: Defiant Netanyahu Defends Judicial Overhaul in Israel
item.description: The prime minister said he planned to reinstate an ally barred from the government. He declined to say if he would respect a Supreme Court decision on the overhaul plan that has divided the country.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with Aryeh Deri, leader of the Shas party, in Parliament in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: Ukraine Offensive Aims for Better Shot at Russian Targets
item.description: Ukraine is hoping that mile-by-mile gains could bring its weapons closer to Russian supply lines, if its forces can overcome Russia’s heavy defense.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian tank in a village that was recaptured by Ukraine’s 110th Territorial Defense Brigade and other forces this month.

item.title: 2 Ukrainian Fighters Take a Break From the War to Marry Each Other
item.description: Their wedding was hosted by a charity group that provides uniforms, boots and other essentials to female soldiers, but because of demand recently started to organize such celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuliya Dluzhynska and Maksym Merezhko at their wedding ceremony in Kyiv.

item.title: Quantum Tech Intended for National Security Is Testing U.S. Alliances
item.description: A global race to harness the power of atoms for navigation, computing and encryption is pitting concerns over protectionism against the spirit of cooperation.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scientist handling a quantum gravimeter prototype at the Q-CTRL laboratory in Sydney, Australia. The version being tested now is 40 times smaller.

item.title: Fire Aboard Cargo Ship off Dutch Coast Is Still Raging
item.description: The vessel, which has about 3,000 vehicles on board, has been burning since Tuesday. One crew member died.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Netherlands Coast Guard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Fremantle Highway, a cargo ship with thousands of vehicles on board, has been burning since Tuesday.

item.title: The State of Women’s Soccer
item.description: The largest-ever Women’s World Cup tournament highlights the growing professionalization of the sport. A sportswriter shares his thoughts.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Aurora Mikalsen of Norway, left, after New Zealand scored during the FIFA Women’s World Cup Australia & New Zealand 2023 in Auckland, New Zealand, this month.

item.title: Head of Presidential Guard Claims Power in Niger Coup
item.description: Gen. Omar Tchiani spoke on state television as the head of a transitional leadership in the West African country, two days after his troops detained the elected president.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Omar Hama Saley
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Télé Sahel, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gen. Omar Tchiani was identified by state television as the president of the National Council for the Safeguarding of the Country.

item.title: Europe Vowed to Make Russia Pay for the War. It’s Not That Easy.
item.description: Confiscating Russian state assets frozen by the United States and Europe could breach international law and set a dangerous precedent, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Destruction from the war in Avdiivka, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: What’s Happening With the Quran Burnings in Sweden?
item.description: Sweden has found itself caught between outrage over anti-Muslim actions and its commitments to free speech.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Iraqi police officers trying to disperse a gathering of protesters on July 20 outside the Swedish Embassy in Baghdad.

item.title: Lebanese Depositors Have Resorted to Force to Withdraw Their Savings
item.description: Amid severe limits on withdrawals and a yearslong financial crisis, Lebanese depositors are resorting to force to demand their own money, earning the moniker “the world’s most honorable bank robbers.”
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walid al-Hajjar looking through photographs of his wife, whose care needs in the final stages of cancer drove him to threaten his bank to get some of his money out.

item.title: Some Israelis Plan to Leave Amid Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul
item.description: Reacting to efforts by the government to take greater control of the judiciary, some people are transferring money overseas and applying for other passports if they are eligible.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Ben Gurion Airport in Israel during anti-government strikes in March. Some are now looking abroad because they feel the country’s democratic nature is being threatened under the Netanyahu government.

item.title: Europe’s Cities Rely on Age-Old Ways to Stay Cool as Heat Waves Intensify
item.description: Architectural styles and construction materials can significantly reduce the need for air-conditioning during heat waves, according to sustainable architecture experts.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Maria Mavropoulou for The New York Times
item.media:description: The whitewashed walls of the buildings in Greece help keep the interiors cool.

item.title: O’Connor Was a Lonely Voice for Change, Until Ireland Changed With Her
item.description: Sinead O’Connor shocked her strongly Catholic country when she tore up the pope’s picture. But the Church’s sexual abuse scandals made Ireland more secular, and more understanding of her criticisms.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: Mourners at a makeshift memorial for Sinead O’Connor, in Bray, Ireland on Thursday.

item.title: Japan Defense White Paper Affirms Stronger Military Strategy
item.description: In a defense white paper, Tokyo presents its case for engagement with allies to respond to threats posed by China and by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Japanese pilots during a multinational military exercise in Guam in February. Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Japan’s defense policy has undergone a rapid evolution.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump faces major new charges.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Trump campaign called the new accusations “desperate and flailing.”

item.title: Sinead O’Connor Mourned in Irish Mountain Village Where She Once Lived
item.description: For three years, the singer, who died this week, found simplicity and happiness in a mountain sanctuary where she was just another neighbor.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Ellius Grace for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sinead O’Connor at her home in Knockananna, Ireland, in 2021.

item.title: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Makes Some Gains, but Questions Remain
item.description: Kyiv has intensified its counteroffensive against the Russian invasion, but has kept things murky on the size of the assault, the casualties and what forces it still has in reserve.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers from the 110th Territorial Defense Brigade flying a reconnaissance drone from their hidden trench position this month near Berdiansk, in the Zaporizhzhia Region.

item.title: Putin, at Summit With African Leaders, Casts West as Mutual Foe
item.description: At a summit in St. Petersburg, Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin offered free grain as he sought to shore up ties with the continent. But lower-than-hoped-for attendance among African leaders hinted at tempering support.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Declan Walsh and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Sergei Bobylyov/TASS, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin greeting President Azali Assoumani of Comoros during a welcoming ceremony at a Russia-Africa summit in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukrainian Fencer Disqualified After Not Shaking Hands With Russian Opponent
item.description: The 17-month war continues to disrupt competitions a year before the Summer Olympic Games in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Gabriela Sá Pessoa and Jeré Longman
item.media:description: Olga Kharlan, left, of Ukraine, refused to shake the hand of Anna Smirnova, of Russia, after their Fencing World Championship bout in Milan on Thursday. Ms. Kharlan’s gesture resulted in her disqualification from the tournament.

item.title: Putin’s Promise of Free Grain Reflects Russia’s Priorities in Africa
item.description: The Russian leader made the overture days after pulling out of the Black Sea grain deal that benefited many countries on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon
item.media:description: A photo released by Russian state media shows President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Russia Africa Summit in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Thursday.

item.title: Oppenheimer and the Chain Reactions of Our Own Making
item.description: The film “Oppenheimer” is not just about the life of a man central to the atomic bomb project: It tells a story of ambition and petty grievances spiraling out of anyone’s control.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: J. Robert Oppenheimer, third from left, with other scientists at a nuclear test site near Alamogordo, N.M.

item.title: Photos Suggest Prigozhin Is in Russia, Meeting African Officials
item.description: The whereabouts of the leader of the Wagner mercenary group has been a subject of continuing questions since an aborted mutiny last month.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne

item.title: Where Wildfires Are Raging in Europe and Africa: Greece, Algeria and More
item.description: Firefighters have scrambled to extinguish blazes in at least 10 countries as a heat wave has swept the Mediterranean region. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Alberto Lo Bianco/LaPresse, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Near Palermo, Sicily, on Wednesday. At least three people have died in fires on the island this week.

item.title: Plan Touching Netanyahu Corruption Case Angers Israel’s Opposition
item.description: The corruption case against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is overseen by the attorney general. Lawmakers in his party proposed stripping her of that responsibility, prompting anger and a swift reversal.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Gali Baharav-Miara, Israel’s attorney general, has been a dissenting voice against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

item.title: King Charles Doesn’t Have as Many Swans as He Used to
item.description: For hundreds of years, the royal family has laid claim to many of England’s swans. An annual count found a worrisome drop in cygnets along a stretch of the River Thames this year.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Swans are counted every year along a stretch of the River Thames in England in what is called a “swan upping.”

item.title: Niger Coup: What to Know
item.description: Military mutineers ousted the country’s elected leader, shaking a pillar of democracy in West Africa.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: How Russia’s State Media Describes Life In Occupied Crimea
item.description: Since Russia invaded Ukraine last year, Russian government officials and state television have hammered home the message that everything is fine.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Putin claims Russian lines are holding.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers preparing to fire mobile artillery toward Russian positions in the Zaporizhzhia region this month.

item.title: After Ousting Qin Gang, China Erases Him and Evades Questions
item.description: China blasted “malicious hype” around the abrupt removal of Qin Gang. The Foreign Ministry’s fumbling response pointed to its diminished influence under Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: China’s former foreign minister, Qin Gang, in Beijing earlier this year.

item.title: Niger’s Detained President Vows to Save Democracy From Coup
item.description: The army chief declared his support for a group of mutineers that seized power on Wednesday. President Mohamed Bazoum and his allies insisted the coup could be reversed.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Elian Peltier and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Nigeriens who supported the military overthrow of the president demonstrated outside the national assembly in Niamey, the capital. A previous rally there had supported the president.

item.title: Once Wary, Biden Welcomes Italy’s Meloni to the White House
item.description: President Biden had feared the electoral victory of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s far-right party last fall would spell trouble. But she has proved to be a strong ally in the American-led effort to support Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy with President Biden at a global infrastructure and investment event in Hiroshima, Japan, in May. Mr. Biden will host the prime minister at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: North Korea Vows Support for Moscow in Visit by Russian Defense Minister
item.description: Pyongyang vowed increased military cooperation against the United States, a common enemy, during a visit by Russia’s defense minister.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korea’s state news media showed Kim Jong Un, center, and Russia’s defense minister, Sergei Shoigu, left, visiting an exhibition of military equipment on Thursday.
